qas.question: Carolina hemlock requires what kind of soil compared to firs?
What kinds of trees are at a lower elevation than Canada hemlocks?

plausible_answers.text: deep, shaded and moist mountain valleys and coves

qas.question: Where are Carolina Hemlocks traditionally found?
What tree contrasted with the Canada hemlock is not affected by the adelgid?

context: Eastern or Canada hemlock (Tsuga canadensis) is another important evergreen needle-leaf conifer that grows along the Appalachian chain from north to south, but is confined to lower elevations than <b2_0>red spruce and the firs<b2_0/>. It generally occupies <b1_0>richer and less acidic<b1_0/> soils than the spruce and firs and is characteristic of <b3_0>deep, shaded and moist mountain valleys and coves<b3_0/>. It is, unfortunately, subject to <b0_0>the hemlock woolly adelgid (Adelges tsugae)<b0_0/>, an introduced insect, that is rapidly extirpating it as a forest tree. Less abundant, and restricted to the southern Appalachians, is <b4_0>Carolina hemlock<b4_0/> (Tsuga caroliniana). Like Canada hemlock, this tree suffers severely from the hemlock woolly adelgid.
